doc.field: Chancellor Schroeder does not rule out faster exit from nuclear power

Federal Chancellor Schroeder said after a meeting of the SPD party committee that he did not consider it impossible to abandon nuclear power earlier than scheduled. The Greens do not want power plants to supply the system for more than 25 years, whereas the SPD demands a remaining operating time of 35 years. According to Schroeder, wishes may always be expressed, but they would have to be measured by whether they are politically feasible. And the partner, who happens to be the energy industry, has a slightly different opinion than the Greens. A dismissal of nuclear power may only take place without any compensation. The chan cellor was, nevertheless, a little bit surprised that the Greens would conduct talks concerning a possible break-away from the government with none other than the energy industry. But chancellor Schroeder looked at this rather calmly.
Conflict about dismissal of nuclear power to be solved on Wednesday

A crisis talk on Wednesday is to clear up the conflict between SPD and Greens concerning the dismissal of nuclear power. However, the Greens referred to reports today claiming a possible compromise between SPD and Greens as "much ado about nothing." The chairperson of the Federal Commission on Nuclear Power Plant Safety, Christoph Matschie, said: "It will also be important what concessions are made by the nuclear power industry. Up to now, the 35-year operating time of nuclear power plants could be considered an offer only. That is not be sufficient. I believe we have to come up with operating times of less than 30 years." The spokesperson of the Greens executive board, Roestel, does not view the coalition to be under any immediate time pressure. It would not be necessary to arrive at a coalition internal solution during Wednesday's meeting.
SPD executive council approves savings measures

The executive council of the SPD agreed to the savings measures of the federal government this afternoon. The highest committee between the party conferences requested that the government consider the possibility of a new capital tax.
Bundestag began its move to Berlin

The historic move of the Bundestag from Bonn to Berlin began according to plan. The first official shuttle with 25 officials and ministerial employees from Bonn landed at the Berlin-Schoenefeld airport today. 40 containers are to be moved by rail from the Rhine to the river Spree by July 31, except for weekends. A total of 9 ministries is to be moved to Berlin.
Hundt sees good chances for Job Alliance

President of the employers' association, Hundt, sees good chances for a new beginning during the talks for a job alliance. Hundt said on Deutschlandfunk that the global political problems had paralyzed Germany's domestic politics during the past months. Hundt was confident that there would be results very soon which would create additional jobs in the federal republic. He was certain that all willing and capable apprentices would receive an offer this year. During tomorrow's talks at the Chancellor's office in Bonn, the president of the employers' association will talk about wage policy, new regulations for working hours, and increased company-based retirement provisions.
Coca-Cola cans with fungus treatment found in Baden-Wuerttemberg

In Baden-Wuerttemberg, small traces of fungus treatment were found in Coca-Cola cans coming from France. The agricultural ministry in Stuttgart reported that it does not expect any health risks from drinking directly from the can due to the low concentration. At the same time, consumers were asked again to look for a German labeling on the can.
4 1/2 year prison sentence for juveniles throwing manhole cover

Two juveniles who had thrown a manhole cover from a bridge have been sentenced to a 4 1/2 year prison term in Essen. The 15 and 17-year-old juveniles had dropped the manhole cover onto a small car late in the evening. The 28-year-old driver was seriously injured and must use a wheelchair since the accident.
Former coach of Telekom cycling team under investigation

A former coach of the Telekom cycling team is being investigated for doping according to the district attorney in Duesseldorf. The spokesperson for the district attorney said to the TV station ARD: "We are investigating an accused person. There is an initial suspicion." But the accused is neither a member nor a coach during the current Tour de France. According to unconfirmed information, the investigation focuses primarily on illegal import of medical drugs during the years 1996 and 1997. The accused has been questioned, but he did not admit to anything according to the district attorney. In addition, various documents had been confiscated.
